content: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:With reference to the Southern Tablelands Education Centre (STEC) Co Op Ltd Commercial Garden Project, which aims to provide training under certain departmental programs for unemployed persons, and the fact that this organisation has leased the property of John McIntyre who is paid by government funds allocated to the STEC:(1) What Commonwealth programs are being used to support this project.(2) What sums of money have been involved and over what time has the STEC received support for the project.(3) What full‐time and part‐time staff are employed under the project.(4) What other resources have been purchased with government funds for this garden project.(5) What accountability measures have been undertaken to ensure that monies are acquitted in accordance with the guidelines.(6) What employment and training complaints relating to wages and contracts have been received by departmental and/or Commonwealth Employment Service officials about the running of this project.(7) Have any complaints concerning occupational health and safety issues been raised by clients undertaking training and employment in this project.(8) Who authorised the employment of John McIntyre, his wife and his son with the STEC.(9) What was the job selection process for these appointments.(10) How many unemployed people, and under what department programs, have gained full‐time or part‐time employment as a result of participation in this specific training project.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Vanstone
content: —The answer to the honourable senators question is as follows:(1) The Commonwealth program that is being used to support this project is New Work Opportunities (NWO).(2) There are two NWO projects, each with approval for 20 participants and each with a budget of $236,000 over 26 weeks. The first stage of the project commenced on 2 January 1996 and will finish on 28 June 1996. The second stage commenced on 5 February 1996 and will finish on 4 August 1996.(3) There are seven staff, two full‐time, one part time and four casual.(4) All resources deemed capital in nature have been leased. These include the leasing of the land, sheds, irrigation system, rotary hoe, portable toilet, pump, toilets and two tractors.All those deemed non capital in nature have been purchased. These include:For participants on the project:Boots, protective clothing, wet weather clothing, first‐aid kits, morning tea amenities, telephone, working clothes, hats, sunscreen and insect repellents, hot water system, kitchen sink, cups, drinking bottles, cleaning materials.Training materials:Drill, drill bits, hammers, welding materials, construction tools, saws, piping, timber, steel, hoes, nuts and bolts, glue and adhesives, shovels, rakes, whiteboard, training videos, text books, notebooks, agricultural facts book, horticulture curriculum, agriculture market reports, fertilisers, insecticides, spray equipment, cleaning materials, ground covers, boxes, petroleum products.Site costs:Water, water storage tank, electricity connection, phone connection, rubbish bins.All these expenditures/purchases are in line with contractual obligations set by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and agreed to by the STEC under the NWO contract and attachments to the contract.(5) Sponsor organisations must ensure that the conditions of the contract are met before any payments are made. These include:The project set‐up costs for each project as outlined in the Project Application, to be paid by the Department to the organisation in two instalments as follows:(a) the first instalment of 80% of the project set‐up costs, paid within 14 days of receipt of the correct invoice for set‐up costs from the STEC but not earlier than one month prior to the commencement of the particular project; and(b) the balance of 20% of the project set‐up costs is to be paid within 14 days of receipt of acceptance by the Department of the Final Financial Statement and Management Report for the particular project. As yet the 20% final payment has not been made to the STEC for either stage of the project.In dollar terms this means that for each stage $76,480 has been paid to the STEC as payment for the 80% set‐up costs for each stage. The remaining 20% will not be paid until the completion of the project.In relation to the Training Allowance costs for the participants on each project these are paid by the Department to the Sponsor organisation in four instalments as set out below:(a) The first instalment, equivalent to 30% of the total Training Allowance costs, paid within 14 days of the Department being advised by the STEC of the starting date for each project and confirmation that the Job Compact clients had been recruited for the project. In this case the first instalment has been paid to STEC for both stages at a cost of $41,145 for Stage I and $41,067 for Stage II.(b) The second instalment, equivalent to 30% of the total Training Allowance costs, paid within 14 days of the STEC providing appropriate evidence that 80% of the first Training Allowance instalment was spent. In this case the STEC provided the necessary evidence for both stages and was paid $41,067 for each stage (total of $82,134).(c) The third instalment, equivalent to 30% of the total Training Allowance costs, paid within 14 days of the Sponsor providing appropriate evidence that 100% of the first Training Allowance instalment and 80% of the second Training Allowance instalment have been spent. The STEC has been paid $41,145 for Stage I and has recently submitted a report, acquittal and invoice for Stage II which are being evaluated.(d) The final instalment, equivalent to 10% of the total Training Allowance costs, paid within 14 days of the Sponsor providing evidence that 80% of the third Training Allowance instalment and 100% of the first and second Training Allowance instalments have been spent. The STEC has not yet submitted an application for the payment of this final instalment for either project.Evidence has to be supplied prior to the payment of the second and subsequent instalments of the project set‐up costs and training allowance costs including a progress report. An acquittal form is required prior to payment of the final payment for the project set‐up costs for each particular project.In respect of this project, payment has been made strictly adhering to the conditions of the contract.(6) Two participants have lodged complaints specifically about wages. Both of these were due to minor clerical errors and were rectified as soon as identified.A complaint was received in the office of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs from a project supervisor who was dismissed by the STEC from his position due to concerns about his supervisory abilities.Some participants have raised concerns with CES staff about the level of supervision on the project and the off‐the‐job training.(7) Complaints were raised concerning occupational health and safety issues, mostly related to working outdoors; the effects of heat and sun during the summer months and working during inclement weather. Participants were supplied with sun protective clothing, sunscreen and wet weather clothing. Participants have also complained about sore backs after bending and picking for long periods.A rail line on the property divides the market garden from the packing shed. As a safety measure the gates are kept closed and crossing of the rail line is only permitted when arriving and departing the work site, during tea breaks and at lunch time.Work Cover officials inspected the site and as a result, additional first aid equipment was purchased, three participants were given additional training in first aid and the condition of the amenities was improved with the construction of a permanent toilet. A complaint involving possible unsafe practices in the use of chemicals was raised by an ex‐employee of the STEC however, Work Cover was unable to find a problem.(8) Mr John McIntyre has never been employed by the STEC but has provided volunteer assistance to the project.Mr Jason McIntyre is a supervisor of the project and initially applied for the position when it was advertised in the local press. Although at that stage he was ranked suitable, he was not selected for the position. Following the dismissal of two other supervisors, Jason McIntyre was appointed with the authorisation of the Chairman of the STEC Board, Mr David Sillett and the Chief Executive Officer, Mr Eric Gordon.Mrs Helen McIntyre was recently appointed by the STEC as a supervisor of the project.(9) All positions, except that which Mrs Helen McIntyre holds, were advertised in the local newspapers or were appointed from internal positions. Formal interviews were conducted and suitable applicants were appointed to the positions.(10) The number of positive outcomes from the project is not yet known as the first stage of the project will not be completed until 28 June 1996. However, recent discussions by Departmental officers with STEC have indicated that it is prepared to employ fourteen trainees working on the property growing and selling produce. It is intended at this stage that some trainees will come from the pool of project participants and others will come from a selection of people on the CES register.N/A

name: Senator Chamarette
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 May 1996:(1) In light of the receipt by the President of correspondence from the Charge DAffaires of the Embassy of the Republic of Iraq, what is the Governments position in relation to the continued sanctions against Iraq, which are still in place more than 5 years after the end of the Gulf War?(2) What are the estimates of the numbers of people who have died as a result of the sanctions?
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Hill
content: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) I am aware of the documents provided by the Iraqi Charge DAffaires to which you refer, as well as the World Health Organisation (WHO) and Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) reports describing the humanitarian situation in Iraq under UN sanctions. I believe the UN Security Council has responded appropriately to the deteriorating situation in Iraq by securing Iraqs agreement on 20 May 1996 to implement UNSCR 986, the third `oil‐for‐food resolution offered by the UN Security Council to the Iraqi Government. It needs to be emphasised that the problems of food supply and distribution in Iraq were imposed by the Iraqi government on the Iraqi people. The agreed procedures for implementing UNSCR 986 will allow Iraq to export a limited amount of oil in return for a UN‐monitored distribution of humanitarian aid to the general Iraqi populace, including Kurdish populations in the North.The Australian Government immediately welcomed this announcement and expressed its full support for the agreement, which will go some way towards alleviating the suffering of the Iraqi civilian population. We should note that the option of addressing the nutritional and health situation of the Iraqi people through this process has been available to the Iraqi Government since 1991, when the UN Security Council adopted UNSCR 706, the first `oil‐for‐food resolution. Further, it has always been within the Iraqi Governments capacity simply to comply with the relevant UNSCRs thus ensuring that sanctions are lifted. As the UN Special Rapporteur on Iraq of the Commission for Human Rights, Mr Max van der Stoel pointed out in his report of March 1996 the Government of Iraq is to be held accountable for any human hardship in Iraq.Prior to agreement being reached on UNSCR 986 the UN Security Council and UN member‐states, conscious of the basic needs of the Iraqi people, specifically exempted food and medical supplies from the sanctions, and provided a facility for the approval of exports to Iraq of essential civilian goods. The UN and many non‐government organisations (including CARE Australia) have throughout the period of sanctions operated an emergency relief program that met some of the needs of Iraqis most affected by sanctions. The Australian Government since 1993/94 has annually contributed a substantial amount in emergency aid to Iraq through multilateral and non‐government channels.As a member‐state of the United Nations, Australia is bound by the 32 United Nations Security Council Resolutions (UNSCRs) on Iraq, including UNSCR 661 which imposed economic sanctions on that state. Sanctions are one of the few non‐military options available to the international community to encourage a Government to behave in a manner that does not threaten international peace and security. Australia has strongly and publicly supported the UN Security Council in maintaining sanctions on Iraq and since 1991 has actively contributed resources to UN activities and organisations such as the UN Special Commission (UNSCOM), overseeing the destruction and ongoing monitoring of Iraqs Weapons of Mass Destruction capacity; and to the Maritime Interception Force (MIF) operating in the Arabian Gulf and Gulf of Aqaba. HMAS Melbourne is currently deployed to the Persian Gulf fulfilling these obligations on behalf of the Australian Government. The Australian Government believes the Government of Iraq must fulfil all remaining aspects of the relevant UN Security Council Resolutions, including accounting for Kuwaitis and third country nationals still missing after the Gulf War, the settlement of reparation claims, and in particular, those relating to the destruction of its WMD capabilities.(2) There appears to be insufficient data available accurately to estimate the effect of sanctions on the Iraqi populace overall. Inevitably, the economic sanctions on Iraq have impacted adversely on many areas of the economy, including basic infrastructure, the environment, local food production, the provision of health services, the rationing of essential supplies, with consequences for the quality of life enjoyed by the average Iraqi citizen, particularly women and children. The 1995 survey conducted jointly by the FAO and the Nutrition Research Institute of the Iraqi Ministry of Health revealed the seriousness of malnutrition amongst Iraqi children. The WHO report of March 1996, comparing the levels of the infant mortality rate and the mortality rate of children under 5 years during the pre‐war period (1988‐89) with that during the period of the sanctions (since 1990), found that the infant mortality rate has doubled and the mortality rate of children under 5 years has increased six times. This is regarded as the result of malnutrition of mothers and children; and the widespread prevalence of infectious diseases. The maternal mortality rate, based on available data, appears to have gone up several fold since 1991. The WHO report recognised that due to the deterioration in the data collection systems in Iraq since 1991, these may underestimate the true situation. It is the Australian Governments view that both the UN and the Government of Iraq have responded responsibly to this situation, by agreeing to implement UNSCR 986. This way of alleviating hardship was long offered by the international community, in the face of obstinacy and intransigence from the Government of Iraq.

name: Senator Colston
content: asked the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, upon notice, on 23 May 1996:(1) What is the current status of discussions with the states and territories and with overseas countries on the issue of the international transfer of prisoners.(2) When does the government expect to introduce legislation on this issue.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Vanstone
content: —The Attorney‐General has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) The government has recently considered the feasibility of developing arrangements to enable prisoners to be transferred between Australia and other countries.In light of the humanitarian, rehabilitative and possible financial benefits, the government has decided to proceed with such a scheme.A substantial amount of work has already been undertaken on this project in the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General (SCAG) forum. The government is continuing to consult closely with the states and territories on this matter, and the proposed legislative and administrative steps will be undertaken in a cooperative manner.Both Commonwealth and state/territory legislation is required to be enacted. The legislation is being drafted by the Parliamentary Counsels Committee at the direction of SCAG. After a lengthy period of consultation and detailed discussions with the states and territories, the draft Commonwealth legislation is now close to being finalised. Parliamentary Counsels Committee, in conjunction with NSW instructors, has also progressed the model state/territory legislation. Both the Commonwealth Bill and the model state/territory legislation are expected to be ready for SCAG endorsement in the near future.The legislation alone will not be sufficient to enable prisoners to be transferred between Australia and other countries. There must also be some form of agreement between Australia and the other country. To this end, the government intends to seek to become party to the Council of Europe Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons, to participate in the Commonwealth Scheme for the Transfer of Convicted Offenders, and to negotiate bilateral treaties with particular countries as appropriate.Some preliminary discussions have already taken place with Thai officials for this purpose. The conclusion of a prisoner transfer agreement with Thailand is a high priority because of the comparatively high number of Australian prisoners in Thai prisons. Any agreement reached with Thailand will not enter into force before Australias legislation (Commonwealth and state/territory) is in place.(2) I am advised that the Commonwealth legislation is expected to be introduced during 1996. It is hoped that the state/territory legislation will be introduced in the parliaments of the participating states and territories at approximately the same time as the Commonwealth legislation is introduced.N/A

content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 1996:(1) How many applications are currently under consideration for entry of imported labour sponsored by Australian companies operating in Western Australia.(2) How many applications have been approved to date in 1996.(3) How many of these applications were justified on the basis of alleged skills shortage in the relevant skills category.(4) What is the breakdown of applications per skills category area where skills shortage is the justification.(5) How many of the companies sponsoring such applications are categorised as body hire/labour hire entities.(6) What is the number of these companies in each skills category.(7) What checks are in place to ensure that all departmental staff are aware of the existing agreements at the national level regarding importation of skilled labour and, in particular, the requirements for formalised labour agreements in certain circumstances.(8) What administrative arrangements are in place to ensure that companies do not lodge applications under different legal entities in order to lodge what effectively amounts to multiple applications.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Short
content: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) The Western Australian office of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) had 90 sponsorship applications under Specialist Temporary Entry visa (sub-class 414), and 33 nominations under the permanent entry Employer Nomination Scheme (sub-class 121), still under consideration as at 25 June 1996.(2) As at 25 June 1996, 386 sponsorship applications under sub-class 414 have been approved by the DIMA Western Australian office.(3) All sponsorship applications for a sub-class 414 visa are assessed against the regulatory requirement that the applicant has trade, technical or professional skills not readily available in Australia. Sponsors are required to undertake labour market testing in order to establish whether or not vacancies can be filled with Australian citizens or Australian permanent residents.Employer nominations are subject to Labour Market testing. Employers must substantiate claims that they cannot find an Australian resident suitable for the position by providing documentary evidence of having tested the Australian labour market or otherwise demonstrating that the necessary skills are not readily available.(4) Details of categories are not currently kept. However, a new computerised sponsorship monitoring system, to be operational from 1 August 1996, will record sponsorship information by industry and occupation.(5) Only the actual employer can be the sponsor of a skilled worker. Recruitment and personnel agencies thus cannot sponsor skilled workers seeking to enter Australia.(6) No figures can be given, as recruitment and personnel agencies cannot sponsor skilled workers seeking to enter Australia.(7) Updated lists of all Labour Agreements are regularly disseminated to all Departmental offices. Departmental guidelines on Labour Agreements are held by each regional office. Staff in regional offices are also expected to consult the Business Branch in Canberra for guidance when the negotiation of a Labour Agreement is being considered.(8) The checking of firms lodging applications is currently undertaken on the basis of manual records. Each case is dealt with according to its individual merits, in particular the demonstrated need for the skilled worker. Cases are dealt with according to the requirements of the Migration Act and Regulations and relevant departmental policy instructions.

name: Senator Chris Evans
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 24 June 1996:Has a decision been taken to close all Western Australian regional offices of the department:(1) If yes: (a) why were the closures handled in such a secretive manner; (b) why was no community consultation undertaken with respect to the closures; (c) what strategies are in place to ensure that there will be no reduction in services to people living in regional centres as a result of the closures; and (d) can an undertaking be given that the decision will be reversed if there is any reduction in service levels.(2) If no: (a) why are department staff holding discussions regarding office closures; and (b) when will there be a public announcement confirming that the offices will remain open.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Newman
content: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) Yes, a decision was taken on 28 June 1996 to close all regional offices of the Department in Western Australia, starting in September and with all closures effected by December 1996. The decision was taken in the context of a review of the viability of the Departments regional network given the reductions in running costs for the Department and the issues which have arisen for the regional offices since opening. These issues relate to the complexity of subject matter, maintaining adequate and appropriate staffing levels and the capacity to keep offices open at all times.(a) The closures have not been handled in a secretive manner. The decision to close the offices was taken on 28 June 1996 and announced to staff on 1 July 1996 and to local members on 2 July. There has been full consultation with staff and unions throughout the review process which led to the final decision on closure. The possibility of office closures was foreshadowed with staff and unions during the review process.(b) The considerations surrounding the decision related to departmental management issues rather than to the community—particularly the capacity to provide in very small offices the depth and breadth of program knowledge necessary to adequately cover the wide range of programs of the Department. These issues needed to be worked through with staff before public announcements. On the other hand, the Department had previously had considerable input from the community on its service needs and priorities. Therefore consultation with the community was not considered appropriate before the decision being made. Officers of the Department have dealt with community concerns as they have arisen in many regions. Consultation with key community stakeholders will form part of the implementation process as the decision is put into effect. This will help ensure that regional focus is maintained in the planning and delivery of services.(c) There will be no reduction in service levels as a result of this decision. The majority of the Departments activities are not related to direct service delivery, but to the funding of community and other organisations to provide services. The implementation process for the closures will include strategies to ensure that a regional focus is maintained while programs are administered from the Perth office of the Department. There will be a particular emphasis on ensuring effective administration and support for services for Aboriginal people.The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service which provides vocational rehabilitation to people with injuries and disabilities is not affected by this decision.(d) As noted under part (c) the decision will not affect levels of service delivery.N/A

name: Senator Woodley
content: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 June 1996:With reference to all commercial fisheries managed by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, either jointly with the States and Territories or otherwise, that involve the technique of long-line fishing for both domestic and foreign vessels:(1) When are commercial fishing licences issued and for which fisheries.(2) How many licences are issued and how often are licences required to be issued and renewed.(3) How does the licence system operate in connection with New South Wales authorities and industries in the absence of an Offshore Constitutional Settlement.(4) To whom are licences currently issued.(5) What environmental impact procedures are required to be carried out prior to the issuing of licences.(6) What fisheries management plans have been finalised under the Commonwealths Fisheries Management Act 1991 for species taken in longline fishing operations.(7) Which species and what numbers of species are caught as `bycatch across all longline fishing operations in Australian coastal waters and the exclusive economic zone.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Parer
content: —The answer to the honourable senators question is as follows:(1) The Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) grants Fishing Permits, Foreign Fishing Licences and Statutory Fishing Rights (SFRs) under the Fisheries Management Act 1991. While these fishing authorities may be granted at any time, for some fisheries they may be granted at the same time each year. At present Fishing Permits, Foreign Fishing Licences and SFRs are current for the following long-line fishing activities:Fishing Permits for using pelagic longlines in the Eastern, Southern and Western Tuna and Billfish Fisheries.Fishing Permits for using pelagic longlines to take shark off south eastern Australia.Fishing Permits for using pelagic longlines in waters adjacent to Christmas Island.Fishing Permits for using demersal longlines to take shark and other demersal species off south eastern Australia. Currently these Permits expire on either 30 June or 31 December.Foreign Fishing Licences for tuna longlining by Japanese vessels under the Bilateral Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the Government of Japan. These are issued annually following agreement of the annual total allowable catch for Southern Bluefin Tuna (SBT). The current Licences will expire on 31 October 1996.SFRs granted under the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery Management Plan 1995 allow for domestic longlining for SBT. These SFRs continue to have effect while the Plan remains in force.(2) The Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) advises that there are currently 245 Australian boats for which Fishing Permits have been granted to allow pelagic longlining and 248 Australian boats for which Fishing Permits have been granted to allow demersal longlining. These Permits are re-granted annually subject to continuing eligibility. In addition, 116 Foreign Fishing Licences have been granted. These Licences will expire on 31 October 1996 and are normally granted annually, subject to the satisfactory conclusion of a Bilateral Agreement with Japan.(3) In the absence of an Offshore Constitutional Settlement (OCS) arrangement, the New South Wales Fisheries Department (the NSW Department) has fisheries jurisdiction of its coastal waters, i.e. out to 3 nautical miles, and AFMA has jurisdiction from 3 nautical miles seaward to the outer limit of the Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ). AFMA grants Fishing Permits for the East Coast Tuna and Billfish Fishery and Statutory Fishing Rights for the SBT fishery in waters under Commonwealth jurisdiction. While the NSW Department licences boats to operate in NSW coastal waters, pelagic longlining and the taking of SBT are prohibited. Under OCS arrangements in force, NSW has jurisdiction over demersal longlining to approximately eighty nautical miles off shore.(4) Eligibility for a Fishing Permit generally depends on satisfying specific criteria that vary from fishery to fishery. Eligibility criteria for the grant of Foreign Fishing Licences for tuna longlining by Japanese vessels under the Bilateral Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the Government of Japan are set out in the Agreement. Eligibility criteria for the grant of SFRs for the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery are set out in the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery Management Plan 1995.(5) Under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (the EPIP Act) AFMA is required to refer to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) any proposal that it believes could affect the environment to a significant extent. The EPA and AFMA have agreed that the formulation of fisheries management plans should be the primary activity assessed under the EPIP Act. Guidelines are in the process of being finalised between the EPA and AFMA which identify broad categories of decisions that as a general rule are not environmentally significant. Licensing decisions fall within one of those categories.(6) The only management plan that covers longlining is the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery Management Plan 1995 which was determined on 3 February 1995.(7) Most pelagic longline fishing in the AFZ involves a number of target species. A number of commercial species may be taken in each longline `shot. In many cases non-target or `bycatch species can form a significant portion of the commercial return to a longline operator.The following table, provided by AFMA, shows information from 1995 logbook returns on the number of fish caught by species in pelagic longline fisheries in the AFZ. content: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 June 1996:With reference to eucalypt species that are approved by the Commonwealth for export as woodchips and sawlogs:(1)(a) Which eucalypt species (scientific and common name) are utilised and exported under Commonwealth approval(b) what is the current range and distribution of these species(c) what national utilisation is made of these species(d) what was the exported volume for each species each year since 1990(e) what are the export destinations for these species.(2)(a) What legal protection is offered for each species in State and Territory jurisdictions, for example, through endangered species legislation and/or other planning controls; and(b) what is the extent of each species representation in protected areas under the jurisdiction of State and Territory national park and wildlife authorities.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Parer
content: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senators questions:For a proper understanding of the issues raised within Senator Woodleys question, a brief background on the Governments forest policy is helpful.The National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) sets out broad conservation and industry goals for the management of Australias forests agreed between the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments. Under the NFPS, Governments agreed to a framework and process for carrying out comprehensive assessments of the economic, social, environmental and heritage values of forest regions. Comprehensive Regional Assessments (CRAs) will provide Governments with the information required to make long‐term decisions about forest use and management. It will be possible to complete a national comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) reserve system which will safeguard biodiversity, old growth, wilderness and other natural and cultural values of forests. It will also be possible to identify the optimal use and management of areas outside the reserve system.The Commonwealth and State Governments have commenced the processes to enable them to negotiate an agreement setting out their obligations in relation to each forest region—a Regional Forest Agreement (RFA). RFAs will give industry the certainty necessary to make the investment which will underpin sustainable industry development, and provide a basis for the management of environmental values through CAR reserves and complementary off‐reserve management.Deferred Forest Assessments (DFAs) evaluated current levels of reservation of old growth, biodiversity and wilderness values and identified additional forest areas that may be required for a CAR reserve system (`deferred forest areas—called `interim forest areas in some States).The Commonwealth developed criteria which were used for the DFA process. Using these criteria, the Commonwealth aimed to ensure that sufficient suitable areas were set aside as deferred forest areas to enable the following indicative benchmarks to be met within well designed and integrated reserves in the ensuing RFA process:(i) a broad benchmark of 15% of the pre‐1750 distribution of each forest community to be protected within the reserve system;(ii) retention in reserves of at least 60% of existing old growth, increasing up to 100% (where practicable) for rare old growth; and(iii) protection of 90%, or more wherever practicable, of areas of high quality wilderness that exceeds minimum size thresholds.The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (the world heritage governing body) and the World Wide Fund for Nature, have suggested 10 per cent of current forest cover as a conservation target. More than 22 per cent of Australias forest estate is protected in conservation reserves (equating to about 14 per cent of pre‐European forest cover).This will ensure that it will be possible to develop well designed and integrated CAR reserves through the ensuing RFA process.The DFA process also sought to maximise the protection of national estate values, threatened and rare species and the extent to which forest communities were represented across their geographic range (`representativeness). The DFA process sought to maximise conservation values while minimising the economic and social costs.(1)(a) Rather than specifically approve or prohibit the export of particular species, the Commonwealth prohibits the export of woodchips produced from timber harvested in deferred forest areas. The Commonwealth also prohibits the export of the following species from Tasmania: coastal Eucalyptus amygdalina, Eucalyptus amygdalina on dolerite, Eucalyptus amygdalina inland, Eucalyptus amygdalina on sandstone, Eucalyptus globulus‐viminalis coastal, Eucalyptus pulchella‐globulus‐viminalis dry, inland Eucalyptus tenuiramis, Eucalyptus viminalis grassy woodland, and Eucalyptus viminalis‐ovata‐rodwayi. I refer Senator Woodley to the Deferred Forest Assessments of December 1995 (called an Interim Forest Assessment for Tasmania), for detailed information on species included in or required for reserves. Other than the aforementioned restrictions, it is a matter for exporters to determine the species of material they utilise.(b) The range and distribution of these species is generally referred to in the Deferred Forest Assessments. These matters are currently being addressed through the CRA process.(c) The utilisation of particular species depends primarily upon their suitability for specific purposes, the commercial viability of their use, and State Government regulatory regimes.(d) Exports of hardwood woodchips (in bone dry tonnes) in each of the calendar years listed below were:N/Amillion bone dry tonnes million green metric tonnes 1990 2.5 4.6 1991 2.7 5.0 1992 2.3 4.2 1993 2.7 5.0 1994 2.4 4.4 1995 2.8 5.1The volumes stated in green metric tonnes represent the broad equivalent of the volumes specified in bone dry tonnes.The conversion factor varies, however, depending upon the moisture content of the wood.N/A(e) Since 1990, hardwood woodchips and logs have been exported to Japan, Taiwan and Korea.(2)(a) The Deferred Forest Assessments contain coverage of State legislative regimes relating to the protection of forest values.(b) The range and distribution of these species is generally referred to in the Deferred Forest Assessments. These matters are currently being addressed through the RFA process.N/A

name: Senator Woodley
content: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 June 1996:With reference to a number of commercial fisheries managed by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) either jointly with the States and Territories or otherwise:(1) What is the current conservation status of the following fish stocks: school, gummy, dusky whaler and sandbar (carcharhinus plumbeus) sharks and the Orange Roughy; Southern Bluefin Tuna and Eastern Gemfish.(2) What conservation measures are being instituted to recover these species.(3) Are the products of school, gummy, or any other sharks exported from Australia: if so, what has the exported volume been for each species, since 1990.(4) What has the exported volume of Orange Roughy been, since 1990.(5) To which destination have shark and Orange Roughy products been bound, since 1990.(6) Is AFMA seeking to have its proposed experimental trawl for the Eastern Gemfish `designated under the Environmental (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.(7) Is the Commonwealth seeking to list the Southern Bluefin Tuna on Appendix II of CITES at the next meeting of the parties in 1997.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Parer
content: —The answer to the honourable senators question is as follows:(1) & (2) The southern bluefin tuna (SBT) is a highly migratory fish that spawns in the Indian Ocean. This species is subject to intense scientific study and international management through the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). In May of this year Australia, Japan, and New Zealand agreed on this years global catch quota for southern bluefin tuna (SBT) at 11,750 tonnes, the same as last years figure. The CCSBT decided national allocations were also the same as last year with 5,265 tonnes to Australia, 6,065 tonnes to Japan, and 420 tonnes to New Zealand.The Commission is a multilateral body established under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea in 1994. The founding members are Australia, Japan, and New Zealand, the three major SBT fishing nations. The global SBT stock has been severely depleted by overfishing, but the Commission is working to ensure that the stock recovers.This years negotiations were particularly difficult and protracted, because Australian and New Zealand scientists have a more pessimistic view of the level of the tuna stock than the Japanese. As a result, Australia and New Zealand did not support a Japanese proposal for a 6,000 tonne increase in the annual catch.The Commission agreed on a substantial program of collaborative scientific work to reduce the uncertainties in our knowledge of the tuna stock. It set down clear objectives and principles for evaluating whether experimental fishing could, in the future, provide for more responsive decision-making in the fishery. The Commission have agreed that management should be directed towards returning to the `biologically safe level of 1980 stock levels by 2020. Setting a target recovery date is a major leap forward for the Commission, although it recognises that the tuna stock may take years to recover from the overfishing of previous decades. The CCSBT next meets in September 1996.Eastern gemfish was an important commercial species for the NSW trawl industry during the late 1970s and 1980s. However, from 1985 to 1989 recruitment of eastern gemfish was greatly reduced. In response, the Australian Fisheries Service, and subsequently AFMA, progressively reduced the total allowable catch (TAC) for eastern gemfish from 3000 tonnes in 1988 to zero in 1993 where it has remained. AFMA also restricted the fishing industry to low `trip limits determined by AFMA each year in consultation with scientists, industry and management. The best estimate of 1995 spawning biomass is between 30 and 35% of 1979 levels, noting that there is still considerable uncertainty surrounding these figures. A major scientific program is currently under way, including limited experimental fishing taking place during the 1996 season which is intended to provide a better estimate of current biomass and its relationship to the management target. Eastern gemfish has been nominated twice under the Commonwealth Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 (ESP Act). Nominations were considered by the Endangered Species Scientific Sub-committee (ESSS) of the Endangered Species Advisory Committee (ESAC). In both cases the Minister for the Environment did not find reason to list the species under the ESP Act.School and Gummy shark form the major catch of the Southern Shark Fishery. They are also taken in zone 2 of the Western Australian southern demersal gillnet and demersal long line fishery. Limitations are in place on the length and construction of gillnets, the number of hooks which can be used, the use of automatic baiting equipment and the size of fish taken. There are also some areas in State waters which have been designated nursery areas in which fishing is prohibited or strictly limited. Catches of gummy shark are considered to be sustainable at current levels. The most recent stock assessment advice for school shark is that recent catches have exceeded the maximum sustainable yield of the stock, and catches need to be reduced. AFMA, in consultation with the Southern Shark Fishery Management Advisory Committee (SharkMAC) is currently developing management arrangements to achieve the necessary reduction in catch. Neither School or Gummy shark are listed on any conservation list.With respect to dusky whaler I assume what is meant is actually dusky shark also known as bronze and black whaler and have answered the question accordingly. Both dusky whaler and sandbar shark have been proposed for listing in the IUCN Red List of Threatened Animals on the basis of the status of these species in the north-west Atlantic—their status in Australia was not considered. In respect of the dusky whaler shark and sandbar shark, both species form part of the catch in the Western Australian southern demersal gillnet and demersal long line fishery. Limitations are in place on the length and construction of gillnets, the number of hooks which can be used, the use of automatic baiting equipment and the size of fish taken. Catches of both species are considered to be sustainable at current levels. However, effort reductions of up to 50% are planned for the fishery in response to stock assessment advice for whiskery sharks.The orange roughy fishery was heavily fished during the late 1980s and early 1990s with a peak annual catch of about 40,000 tonnes. It is managed as three sub-fisheries as each is believed to contain a discrete fish stock. The main spawning stock off eastern Tasmania and the southern stock have been under TACs since 1990. A TAC was introduced to the western zone in 1992. Current estimates indicate that spawning biomass of the eastern and southern stocks are around 25 to 30 percent of 1988 levels depending on assumptions about stock structure and natural mortality rates. The status of the western orange roughy fishery is unknown. AFMA has set an objective of rebuilding the eastern/southern stocks to 30% of 1988 spawning biomass by 2004. This has required continued reductions in the southern zone TAC from 10,000 tonnes in 1993 to 3,000 tonnes in 1996. The TAC is expected to be reduced further to 1,500 tonnes by 1998. The eastern and western zone TACs are stable at 2,000 tonnes and 1,500 tonnes respectively. Research is continuing into better understanding the stock structure of orange roughy as this impacts on the achievement of management objectives for the fishery.(3) (4) & (5) Most of the products of school, gummy and other sharks are marketed domestically. School and gummy sharks are primarily retailed as `flake in Australia in the form of fillets or headed, gilled and gutted trunks. Australia is a net importer of shark meat for consumption principally in the Melbourne market. Australia does export a number of shark products principally fins, shark liver oil and shark cartilage although information on the quantity of these exports are not recorded. Information is not collected on exports of shark by species although total exports of shark for human consumption are recorded.N/AExport of shark for human consumptionYear Destination Total (kg) 1990 Japan 50 1991 Japan, Taiwan 274 461 1992 Singapore, Taiwan 3895 1993 Hong Kong, Singapore 1550 1994 Japan 5000 1995 New Zealand, Singapore 3007Source: Australian Bureau of StatisticsExports of orange roughy are not recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. However, most of Australias orange roughy production is exported as fillets to the United States. The Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics (ABARE) estimates that around 75 percent of exports of fillets from Australia to the United States are orange roughy.Export of fillets to the United StatesYear Total(000kg) Orange Roughy*(000kg) 1989-90 7152 5364 1990-91 6632 4974 1991-92 4199 3149 1992-93 3568 2676 1993-94 2182 1637 1994-95 1098 824Source: Australian Bureau of Statistics, ABARE. * ABARE estimate(6) AFMA advises that during the initial development of the research proposal for a gemfish experimental trawl, the Authority wrote to the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (EPA) seek ing its endorsement for the take of up to 200 tonnes of eastern gemfish during the survey. AFMA also wrote to the Executive Director of the Endangered Species Scientific Sub-committee informing him of the survey and that AFMA had written to the EPA seeking its endorsement. The EPA suggested to AFMA that it designate the survey proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (EPIP Act) as it was of the view that the proposed harvest from the research program, combined with the bycatch harvest, would amount to a significant portion of the existing stock. In the light of this advice, AFMA requested the CSIRO to undertake an analysis of the effects on the spawning stock of taking 300 tonnes, comprising 200 tonnes during the survey and 100 tonnes under bycatch trip limits, during 1996. The CSIRO analyses showed that the impact of the trawl survey on the eastern gemfish stock would be small. AFMA then wrote to the EPA and advised that in view of the CSIRO advice it had decided that it was not necessary to designate the proposal under the EPIP Act and that it would therefore be going ahead with the trawl survey. I understand that the trawl survey commenced on 17 June 1996 and is due to be completed prior to 8 August 1996.(7) There is no Australian Government proposal to list the Southern Bluefin Tuna on Appendix II of CITES at the next meeting of the parties in 1997. However, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency (ANCA) has commissioned a scientific assessment by CSIRO of the likelihood of Southern Bluefin Tuna meeting the criteria for listing on CITES. ANCA has indicated that this assessment is being undertaken to provide the agency with information needed for developing a whole of government approach in relation to CITES issues and Southern Bluefin Tuna. ANCA has indicated that any consideration of a possible listing of Southern Bluefin Tuna in the future will be carried in full consultation with relevant Government agencies, industry and other interest groups.N/A

name: Senator Margetts
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 June 1996:(1) With reference to the decision of 24 July 1989 when the Hon. Lionel Bowen permitted Australian forces to act as mercenaries against the Bougainville people: (a) do Australian servicemen or ex‐servicemen continue to play this role in the Bougainville conflict; (b) if so, does Australia sanction this behaviour and under which international or domestic laws or principles.(2) With reference to the current renewed offensive by the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Government against Bougainville which has resulted in many deaths and injuries: (a) how is this new offensive being financed by PNG; (b) is the Australian government providing any funding towards the PNG offensive; if so, how much funding and under what programs; (c) has the Government provided funding in the past which the PNG Government could now be using to fund its offensive in Bougainville; (d) if so, what action can the Australian government take to stop this from happening; (e) can an absolute guarantee be made that no Australian money is being used to fund the current offensive in Bougainville; (f) is it the case that PNG would be using its World Bank loan to fund the offensive in Bougainville; if so, how is this possible; and (g) can the PNG Government afford the $10 million budget for the Bougainville offensive; if not, can details be provided of any outside involvement, and who is funding the offensive and to what extent.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Newman
content: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) I am aware of a declaration made on 20 July 1989 by the then Attorney‐General which permitted the recruitment in Australia by the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Government of persons to serve with the PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) in any capacity to facilitate the use of four Iroquois helicopters supplied to the PNG Government by the Australian Government. In respect of this decision:(a) Currently serving Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel are specifically excluded from the terms of that decision. With regard toex‐ADF personnel, the Department of Defence does not hold records of the employment of individual Australian civilians, whether ex‐ADF or otherwise, by civilian companies which contract to the PNGDF or by the PNGDF itself.(b) Employment of Australian civilians, whether by the PNGDF or by contractors to it, is permitted under the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978.(2) (a) I am informed that Operation HIGH SPEED II was financed by the PNG Government through a one‐off, A$10M supplement to its defence budget.(b),(c) and (d)Australia does not provide direct support to, or funding towards, PNGDF operations on Bougainville, including HIGH SPEED II.(e) Australia provides significant budget support to the PNG Government, which is currently being phased out and replaced by specifically‐targeted program assistance. The allocation and expenditure of the direct budget support Australia provides is a matter for the PNG Government to decide.(f) The PNG Governments allocation and expenditure of World Bank loan monies is a matter between the World Bank and the PNG Government.(g) It is up to the PNG Government to decide how it allocates and spends its own resources.N/A

content: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 1 July 1996:(1) Are areas of the Western Australian State forest that are entered on the interim list of the register of the National Estate protected under current woodchip export licences; if so, in what manner.(2) If such areas are protected under woodchip export licences, can a commitment be given that protection will be retained under 1997 licences.(3) Has the Minister given permission to any company or person to export woodchips sourced from interim listed areas.(4) Does the Minister intend to give permission to any company or person to export woodchips sourced from interim listed areas.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Hill
content: —The answer to the honourable senators question is as follows:(1) The Western Australian and Commonwealth Governments have recently signed a Deferred Forest Agreement (DFA) which ensures that areas which may be required for a comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) reserve system are not available for timber harvesting pending the negotiation of a Regional Forest Agreement (RFA). In addition, a voluntary undertaking by the Western Australian Government protects from timber harvesting, until 31 December 1996, all forest areas that are listed or interim listed in the Register of the National Estate.(2) The Western Australian Government has also given a voluntary undertaking to protect from timber harvesting certain National Estate forest areas where the DFA identified old growth forests requiring interim protection to meet Commonwealth reserve criteria benchmarks. Jane and Sharpe forest blocks, and part of Giblett forest block, will also be protected under this voluntary arrangement. Maps of these areas are available from the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM). The interim protection of these areas remains in force until 31 December 1997, or until signature of a RFA, whichever is sooner.(3) Under the provisions of the Export Control Act 1982, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is the Minister responsible for woodchip export licence approvals. I understand, however, that current licences prohibit the export of woodchips sourced from these areas.(4) The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy approves woodchip export licences.A Commonwealth team which includes my department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, is currently scoping a Comprehensive Regional Assessment (CRA) to identify forest values across the South West forest region of Western Australia. This CRA will form the basis for the development of a RFA for the South West Forests. The RFA will provide the framework for future conservation and resource allocation decisions, including the issuing of woodchip export licences.N/A

name: Senator Lees
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 2 July 1996:(1) Does the department monitor information and data relating to the recognised international physiological norms for breathing rates, as measured by minute volume; if so, what are those norms.(2) What studies have been done in Australia on the incidence of hyperventilation in the Australian population.(3) What are the known consequences of hyperventilation for health.(4) What are the Australian morbidity and mortality figures for diseases in which hyperventilation is a contributory factor.(5) What are the available remedies for hyperventilation in Australia.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Newman
content: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) No, the department does not monitor this information.(2) The National Health and Medical Research Council has not, over the past ten years, funded any studies relating to the incidence of hyperventilation in the Australian population. A search of a large data base of published medical literature (Medline) indicates that no studies have been published on this issue in Australia over the last five years.(3) Hyperventilation is associated with increased respiratory drive, an increased minute volume of ventilation, muscle effort and there is a reduction in the content of arterial carbon dioxide. The latter is expressed as the partial pressure of arterial carbon dioxide and the normal range is 37 to 43 mmHg. Effects of decreased arterial carbon dioxide include disturbances in acid/base balance and reductions in levels of free calcium and phosphate in blood. These metabolic disturbances may lead to a well recognised array of symptoms. Such metabolic disturbances are reversible upon restoration to normal carbon dioxide content.(4) The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has advised that for the period 1990‐1994, there were no deaths in Australia resulting from hyperventilation syndrome or psychogenic/anxiety hyperventilation. Morbidity data show that during the financial years 1991‐1992 and 1992‐1993, there were 366 separations from all Australian public, DVA and private hospitals (excluding Victorian, ACT and NT private hospitals) which may have been associated with hyperventilation; ie 366 separations having a principal or secondary diagnosis recorded as: a respiratory physiological malfunction arising from mental factors, eg air hunger, cough, hiccough, yawning, or hyperventilation.(5) There are a number of disease states which can be associated with hyperventilation and the management is the treatment of the underlying condition.For those people who develop significant symptoms during an acute attack, inhalation of a low concentration of carbon dioxide can be very beneficial, for example, rebreathing through a paper bag.For those with disabling underlying psychogenic hyperventilation, careful assessment and therapy can be provided by a medical practitioner.N/A

name: Senator Woodley
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 22 July 1996:With reference to reports of a live cattle shipment of 10,500 steers from Port Adelaide to Egypt in May 1996:(1) Is it a fact that this was Australias largest shipment of live cattle.(2) Is the Government planning to expand live cattle exports.(3) Do live cattle shipments need to be authorised by the Federal Government; if so, under what particular Act or Acts are live cattle shipments authorised.(4) (a) What animal welfare guidelines are currently in place for cattle subjected to transportation in this manner; and (b) are these guidelines legally enforceable; if so by whom; if not, are these guidelines voluntary.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Parer
content: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senators question:(1) I am advised that a shipment of live cattle from Port Adelaide to Egypt on 27 May 1996 carried almost 10,500 head and this was the largest single shipment of cattle from Australia to that date in 1996.(2) Live cattle exports are arranged on commercial terms subject to market demand and the availability of suitable stock. This is a legitimate trade. The Government generally encourages increased exports of Australian products but has no specific responsibility for planning the level of live cattle exports.(3) Livestock exporters are licensed by the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Corporation (AMLC), under the Meat and Live‐stock Industry Act 1995. Licensed exporters seek approval from the AMLC for exports, and are subject to compliance with orders issued by the AMLC. Notification of intention to export is made to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, which issues appropriate health certification and permits to export animals under the Export Control Act 1982.(4) (a) & (b) A Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals: Sea Transport of Livestock, was endorsed by Commonwealth and State Ministers meeting in the Australian Agricultural Council in July 1988. The Code is a voluntary guide for people responsible for the welfare and husbandry of animals during sea transport.Marine Orders, Part 43, Cargo and Cargo Handling—Livestock, issued by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) pursuant to the Navigation Act 1912, provides the basis for ensuring vessels carrying livestock meet Australian requirements. The Orders include provisions relating to ship design, fodder and water supplies, fitness of livestock, the number that may be carried, the design and arrangement of pens and care of livestock on board. The Orders allow penal provisions to be applied by AMSA.Commonwealth Departments and Authorities maintain close links with representatives of the livestock export industry, individual exporters, the AMLC and significant animal welfare groups to ensure due consideration is given to welfare aspects of the live animal export trade.N/A

name: Senator Knowles
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 30 November 1995:(1) What was the outcome of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Western Australia task force investigation into and report on federal grants made to the Nomads Charitable and Education Foundation and the Strelley organisation.(2) Were allegations that ATSIC funds had been syphoned into private companies by Nomads Charitable and Education Foundation investigated by ATSIC; if so (a) what was the outcome of those investigations; and (b) how much federal money was found to have been diverted to private companies.(3) What federal funds are still being directed to either Strelley, Carlindie, Warralong, Woodstock or Lalla Rookh stations in the Pilbara region of Western Australia.(4) How many sheep or cattle stations does ATSIC own.(5) What evidence exists to show that other stations around Australia which receive Community Development Employment Program funding from the Government have fallen into a state of disrepair or been abandoned like Strelley Station in Western Australia.(6) What checks are made by ATSIC or other authorities on these properties to ensure they are functioning as intended.(7) What happens if they are not functioning as intended.(8) What happened to the assets of Strelley Station after it was found to have been abandoned; and (b) did ATSIC attempt to recover surplus funds.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Herron
content: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senators question:(1) The Strelley Nomads Task Force Review was undertaken from June‐September 1993 to investigate a number of matters relating to funds allocated by ATSIC to the Strelley Nomads organisation. The Task Force recommended that no further funding be made available to the Strelley Housing Society Incorporated and the Nomads Charitable and Education Foundation Incorporated until completion of an independent audit of the organisations.This independent audit investigation was undertaken by Duesburys Chartered Accountants and was completed in November 1995. A summary of the key findings of the investigation is attached for your information—see Attachment A.(2) Allegations that ATSIC funds had been syphoned into private companies by Nomads Charitable and Education Foundation were investigated within the context of the Duesburys independent financial investigation. This investigation looked at all funds granted by ATSIC to the Strelley Housing Society Incorporated (Strelley ) and the Nomads Charitable and Educational Foundation Incorporated (Nomads).Parts six and seven of the Terms of Reference for the investigation related to investigating the transfer of funds. A copy of the Terms of Reference is attached for your information—see Attachment B.(a) One of the areas of concern noted in the Duesburys report is the extent of transactions between Strelley Nomads and related parties. It would appear that the supporting documentation for these transactions was minimal, with no breakdowns of the amounts charged.(b) Duesburys advised in its investigation report that it did not have the right to access the financial records of the related entities to determine if the services provided were charged at realistic rates. However, the following instances were cited as examples of concerns about funds paid to related parties:1990/91 Health FundingAccounting and Audit FeesAmounts totalling $10,000 were paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. The invoices from the related party did not detail the nature or extent of the services provided and did not detail the audit fees paid to the external auditor.Airfares and CharterAmounts totalling $55,000 were paid to Nomads (1966) Pty Ltd during the year. Nomads were unable to provide documentary evidence as to the nature and extent of the services provided by Nomads (1966) Pty Ltd.1991/92 Health FundingAirfares and CharterAmounts totalling $55,000 were paid to Nomads (1966) Pty Ltd during the year. Nomads were unable to provide documentary evidence as to the nature and extent of the services provided by Nomads (1966) Pty Ltd.Wages—Part‐time BookkeeperAmounts totalling $12,122 were paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year for the services of a part‐time bookkeeper. Duesburys was not able to ascertain which employees this charge related to and Nomads was unable to provide documentary evidence as to the nature and extent of the services provided by Nomads (1966) Pty Ltd.1992/93 Health FundingAccounting and Audit FeesAmounts totalling $9,000, equal to the budgeted amount, were paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to establish what services were provided or what component of this fee represented audit fees paid to external parties.Airfares and CharterFour quarterly charges of $12,669, totalling $50,676, equal to the budgeted amount, were paid to Nomads (1966) Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to access any flight records or otherwise verify the number of flights for which the plane was used.1993/94 Health FundingAccounting and Audit Fees$1,500 was paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to establish what services were provided or what component of this fee represented audit fees paid to external parties.1990/91 Community Infrastructure FundingCapital—Warralong Airstrip$48,000 was paid to Nomads (1966) Pty Ltd as payment for completion of 80% of work on improvements to the Warralong Airstrip. Duesburys was not able to obtain any external documentation supporting this payment or details regarding dates on which work was completed or equipment used.Wages—Non‐AboriginalAmounts totalling $26,445 were charged to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to establish which individuals were employed or where these employees are located.1991/92 Community Infrastructure FundingWages—Non‐Aboriginal$25,886 was paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to establish which individuals were employed or where these employees were located.Accounting and Audit$8,000 was paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to establish what services were provided or what component of this fee represented audit fees paid to external parties.1992/93 Community Infrastructure FundingWages—Non‐Aboriginal$27,180 was paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to establish which individuals were employed or where these employees were located.Accounting and Audit$8,400 was paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd during the year. Duesburys was not able to establish what services were provided or what component of this fee represented audit fees paid to external parties.(3) ATSIC is not aware of any Commonwealth funds being directed to the Strelley, Carlindie, Warralong, Woodstock or Lalla Rookh stations for pastoral activities. The only funding allocated by ATSIC has been to the Warralong community, which is situated on the Warralong pastoral lease. Funding to this community had been for Community Infrastructure and a Community Development Employment Project.(4) ATSIC has a policy to divest itself of all pastoral properties. Properties are instead vested in the appropriate Aboriginal Corporation. This process is almost completed and ATSIC now only owns four pastoral properties in Western Australia.(5) It is acknowledged that some pastoral stations do not have adequate facilities for all residents or may have been abandoned for short periods due largely to seasonal factors. However, the provision of Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) funding to Aboriginal organisations is separate from any funding for pastoral operations being undertaken by these organisations. In terms of the CDEP ATSIC is only responsible for ensuring that CDEP work activities are being carried out in accordance with the work plan, that wages are paid to participants and that regular CDEP Reviews are carried out. Where an organisation has temporarily left a property, it is likely that CDEP activities are no longer being performed and the CDEP project would be suspended or ceased accordingly. ATSIC is not responsible for the monitoring of pastoral properties that are not in receipt of ATSIC funding—in fact ATSIC has no authority to become involved unless it is providing funding.(6) While ATSIC is not responsible for the monitoring of all pastoral properties, ATSICs Regional Offices routinely visit pastoral stations in Western Australia in receipt of ATSIC funds to ensure that the properties are being managed properly and are operating at a sustainable level. Regional Offices are also responsible for conducting regular visits of CDEP programs on these pastoral properties to check participant schedules and work performed.Furthermore, ATSICs Western Australian State Office conducts regular Reviews of those pastoral stations in receipt of ATSIC land management funding to ensure that funds are being expended in accordance with ATSICs requirements. Those organisations operating the stations are also required to adhere to ATSICs reporting requirements by providing audited financial statements.ATSIC recently signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Western Australian Department of Agriculture to monitor all pastoral properties in the Pilbara and Upper Gascoyne regions. This has involved the use of a pastoral adviser to monitor the operations of each property. In the Kimberley region, 18 pastoral properties are participants to the Kimberley Aboriginal Pastoralists Project (KAPP), which is aimed at developing all properties to their maximum potential. ATSIC fully supports this project and has provided funding to assist in its development.In addition, the leases on all pastoral properties are monitored by the Pastoral Board of Western Australia to ensure that lease conditions are being met. In the case of Strelley, it is understood that the Pastoral Board has been in contact with the Strelley Nomads organisation about the current condition of the organisations pastoral leases.(7) It is the responsibility of the Pastoral Board of Western Australia to ensure that organisations are operating their pastoral properties in accordance with the conditions of their pastoral lease. Should an organisations pastoral operations be in breach of its lease conditions, the Pastoral Board has the authority to withdraw the lease.ATSICs role in such matters is to ensure that ATSIC grant funds are being accounted for. ATSIC is only in a position to provide advice and assistance should pastoral activities not be operating at a sustainable level. This may include arranging for the appointment of a pastoral consultant or provid ing additional funding. Initiatives such as the MOU signed with the Department of Agriculture are intended to provide ongoing assistance that may not be possible due to ATSICs limited resources.(8)(a) The Strelley Task Force Review Report indicated that the Strelley station was abandoned in 1984 because of its proximity to the South and Port Hedland townships. However, it was not until 1991 that Strelley Nomads gave the State Energy Commission of Western Australia authorisation for all salvageable equipment at the station to be removed.However, considerable infrastructure still remains at the station. ATSICs predecessor, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, had recognised the need to identify and secure those Government funded assets provided for Aboriginal people associated with the Strelley Nomads organisation.The Duesburys investigation was able to identify all remaining assets in the possession of Strelley Nomads that were purchased with ATSIC funding. However, Duesburys did not inspect these assets and could not verify the locations of these assets as had been provided by Strelley Nomads.ATSIC is currently deciding on an appropriate course of action to recover the assets.(b) The Duesburys investigation was able to identify all remaining ATSIC grant surpluses held by the Strelley Nomads organisation. ATSIC has since commenced action to issue a Section 20 Notice to Strelley Nomads to recover these remaining surpluses.Because of remaining concerns about the syphoning of monies into private companies, and because the consultant engaged by ATSIC did not have the right to access the records of the related entities, ATSIC has decided to refer the matter to the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) for further investigation. The ASC is the appropriate statutory body to examine these issues.

name: Senator Hill
content: —On 27 June 1996 ( Hansard page 2385) Senator Robert Ray asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney‐General the following questions without notice:(1) Is it a fact that various state branches of the National Crime Authority (NCA) have been notified of budget cuts well in advance of the budget.N/A(2) Is it true that the proposed coalition cuts that appeared in your election manifesto have been doubled and that this will mean vastly reduced operations in both Western Australia and South Australia.(3) Can the minister guarantee that the NCA will remain an effective weapon against organised crime.(4) Can the minister assure the Senate that the cuts were not inspired by the malicious attack on the NCA by the Premier of Victoria, who subsequently had to apologise to the Supreme Court.The Attorney‐General has provided the following answers to the honourable senators questions:N/A(1) Yes. Proposals to make savings in the NCA budget were outlined in the Coalitions election statement `Meeting Our Commitments in February this year. These proposals are now firm requirements that the NCA take measures to reduce outlays in order to meet savings targets set by the Government.(2) The NCA determines what steps will be taken to achieve its savings targets. As you may be aware, the Chairperson of the NCA recently announced cuts in both corporate and operational areas of the NCA as part of its savings strategy. The decision by the Chairperson to make substantial cuts to the NCAs Perth and Adelaide offices was based on an assessment of the relative level and impact of organised criminal activity in those jurisdictions, compared with that in other States. Despite the cutbacks, the NCA is retaining a core team of staff in its Perth and Adelaide offices so that it maintains a presence in all of its existing locations across Australia.(3) I have previously recognised publicly that any savings by the NCA may result in a reduction in its criminal investigation capacity. Available resources have, however, been allocated to minimise the impact of the cuts on the NCAs core investigative functions.(4) As I have already stated, these cuts were foreshadowed in the coalitions election statement in February. The Government has set savings targets for all Government departments and agencies. The NCA is simply one of those Government agencies required to meet those targets.N/A
